reality.title: Reality Check
reality.realisticDescription: Typical influences from ground, buildings, and vegetation

coverage.nvis: NVIS mode: Signal radiates nearly straight up and reflects back almost vertically. Ideal for contacts up to ~500 km with no skip zone.
coverage.regional: Regional coverage: Medium takeoff angle enables contacts between 300-1500 km. Small skip zone possible.
coverage.dx: DX mode: Low takeoff angle for long-distance contacts 1000-4000 km. Skip zone in the near field.
coverage.worldwide: Worldwide DX: Very low angle enables multi-hop propagation. Range up to 20,000 km, but large skip zone.
coverage.noNvis: This band doesn't support NVIS. The frequency is too high for steep reflection.

2200m.info: LF band - requires extremely large antennas, very specialized

630m.info: MF band - long antennas required, good ground wave propagation

160m.range: Regional to 2000 km at night, NVIS during day
160m.info: The 'Top Band' - high atmospheric noise, requires large antennas

80m.range: NVIS during day (~500 km), DX at night to 3000 km
80m.info: Classic regional band, good for local nets

60m.info: Secondary allocation, good compromise between 80m and 40m

40m.range: NVIS during day, DX to 10,000 km at night
40m.info: The all-round band - works almost always somehow

30m.info: CW/Digital only, no NVIS, good DX compromise

20m.info: THE DX band - worldwide when sunspots are up

17m.info: WARC band, less crowded, needs solar activity

12m.info: WARC band, opens only with good conditions

10m.info: Highly dependent on solar activity, magic openings possible

6m.info: The 'Magic Band' - surprising openings, almost like VHF

4m.info: 70 MHz band - available in some countries, good Sporadic-E potential

2m.info: The classic VHF band - FM, SSB, digital modes, satellites

70cm.info: Very versatile - FM, repeaters, ATV, satellites, EME

23cm.info: Microwave entry point - EME, tropo, ATV, QO-100 uplink

13cm.info: 2.4 GHz - QO-100 downlink, ATV, beacon operation

3cm.info: 10 GHz - most popular microwave band, rain scatter, beacons

dipole.low: Low dipole = high angle radiation. Ideal for NVIS (local contacts up to 500 km). Signal goes nearly straight up and comes back down in the vicinity.
dipole.medium: Medium height = balanced pattern. Compromise between local and DX. Good for nets and general operation.
dipole.high: High dipole = low angle radiation. Better for DX, but skip zone nearby. Higher is better for long-distance contacts.

vertical.low: Verticals radiate at low angles by nature - ideal for DX. But: ground quality is crucial! Without good radials or moist ground, you lose a lot of energy.
vertical.medium: Radials matter more than height! 16+ radials of 1/4λ dramatically improve efficiency. Saltwater or wet meadow are natural 'radials'.
vertical.high: More height doesn't help verticals much - the feedpoint should be near ground. Invest in radials rather than a taller mast.

vertical58.low: The 5/8λ vertical has ~2 dB more gain than 1/4λ due to lower radiation angle. But requires matching network (coil or stub).
vertical58.medium: Typical VHF/UHF antenna: 5/8λ above ground or counterpoise. The gain comes from concentrating radiation in the horizontal plane.
vertical58.high: Unlike the 1/4λ vertical, the 5/8λ always needs a matching network - the impedance is not directly 50 ohms.

collinear.low: The Collinear stacks multiple radiators vertically for even lower radiation angle and more gain (5-6 dBi).
collinear.medium: Typical technology for VHF/UHF repeater stations. Consists of multiple 5/8λ elements with phasing sections.
collinear.high: The more elements, the higher the gain, but also more complex construction. Typically 2-4 elements for amateur use.

invertedV.low: The Inverted-V is a great compromise: needs only one mast in the middle and radiates somewhat more omnidirectionally than a flat dipole.
invertedV.medium: Watch the included angle: 90-120° between legs is ideal. Too flat = too much high-angle radiation, too steep = mechanically unstable.
invertedV.high: When mounted higher, the pattern approaches that of a horizontal dipole. Still retains the advantage of simple construction.

efhw.low: The EFHW (End-Fed Half-Wave) behaves similar to a dipole but needs only one support point. Great for portable setups.
efhw.medium: Advantage: Multi-band capable with matching unun (49:1). Disadvantage: More sensitive to RF in the shack, good grounding important.
efhw.high: Mounted high, the EFHW becomes a serious DX antenna. The wire can run at an angle - flexibility is the main advantage.

randomWire.low: A random wire is the 'emergency antenna' - any wire, hung up somehow. Works surprisingly often, but the pattern is unpredictable.
randomWire.medium: With an antenna tuner, almost anything works. Efficiency varies greatly depending on length and mounting. Experimentation is key!
randomWire.high: Length matters more than shape. 20-40m of wire, as high and clear as possible, gives surprising results even without optimization.

deltaLoop.low: The Delta Loop has ~1 dB gain over a dipole and radiates at relatively low angles when mounted horizontally - good for DX.
deltaLoop.medium: Triangle shape: one corner at the mast top, two at the bottom. Needs less height than a dipole for comparable DX performance.
deltaLoop.high: At full wavelength circumference (e.g., 40m on 40m band), the loop shows its full potential. Also good for receiving.

g5rv.low: The G5RV is a multiband compromise: a 31m dipole with 10m ladder line as matching. Works on 80-10m with a tuner.
g5rv.medium: No optimal SWR on any band, but 'good enough' everywhere. The ladder line should run as vertically as possible.
g5rv.high: Classic for hams with limited space. Not the best antenna for any single band, but the most practical for all of them.

yagi2el.low: A 2-element Yagi focuses the signal in one direction (~5 dBd gain). Less power needed, but you must know where to point it!
yagi2el.medium: Yagis need height and clear view. A rotator makes them truly useful. For a fixed direction (e.g., USA) also useful without rotator.
yagi2el.high: On 20m or higher, the Yagi becomes manageable. On 40m it's a project, on 80m you need a farm.

yagi3el.low: 3 elements = more gain (~8 dBd), narrower beam, better front-to-back ratio. The serious DX antenna.
yagi3el.medium: Watch the boom length: about 6m on 20m, about 4m on 15m. Don't underestimate wind and ice loading!
yagi3el.high: High on a mast, a 3-element Yagi is a DX machine. Combined with a good location = pile-up killer.

yagi4el.low: 4 elements bring ~9 dBd gain. The boom gets longer, but front-to-back ratio improves further.
yagi4el.medium: From 4 elements, wind load becomes a real issue. On 20m already ~8m boom length! Mechanics are as important as electronics.
yagi4el.high: Mounted high, an excellent DX antenna. The narrower beam means: aim more precisely, but more signal at the target.

yagi5el.low: 5 elements = ~10 dBd gain. Already a 'large' antenna, typical for contest stations and DXers.
yagi5el.medium: Boom gets very long (10m+ on 20m). Needs a sturdy rotator and strong mast. F/B ratio is excellent.
yagi5el.high: A 5-element Yagi high on a mast is a pile-up breaking weapon. Serious equipment for serious DX hunters.

yagi6el.low: 6 elements bring ~11 dBd - that's 12× the power of a dipole in one direction! But: size and complexity increase.
yagi6el.medium: Typical for 10m/15m bands where the antenna is still manageable. On 20m you need a farm and a crane.
yagi6el.high: A 6-element Yagi is contest and DXpedition equipment. Combined with low-band verticals the ultimate setup.

magloop.low: The Magnetic Loop is small, efficient, and radiates at high angles - ideal for NVIS and space-limited situations (balcony, attic).
magloop.medium: Very narrowband! Retune after every QSY. But: low-noise reception and no radials needed.
magloop.high: Can be used indoors, but outdoors is better. Tuning is critical - motorized tuning highly recommended.

windom.low: The Windom (OCF Dipole) is fed off-center. This allows multiband operation without a tuner. Lower = more high-angle radiation.
windom.medium: Feed point is at ~1/3 of total length. Matches 50 ohms with 4:1 or 6:1 balun. Good multiband compromise.
windom.high: Mounted high, the Windom behaves like a good DX dipole. The asymmetry adds slight directivity - can be advantage or disadvantage.

zepp.low: The Zepp antenna is end-fed via ladder line. Low mounting for regional contacts, but it's naturally more of a DX antenna.
zepp.medium: Advantage: Very efficient as no current needs to flow at the feed point. Works well on harmonics of the fundamental frequency.
zepp.high: The classic Zepp was the antenna of the Zeppelins. Today popular as multiband DX antenna with low-angle radiation.

edz.low: The Extended Double Zepp (EDZ) is 1.28λ long - yielding ~4 dBd gain bidirectionally. Needs more space than a dipole.
edz.medium: The EDZ radiates in two directions with high gain. Ideal when you have two preferred directions (e.g., USA and Japan).
edz.high: Mounted high, the EDZ is one of the best wire antennas for DX. Ladder line feed makes it usable on multiple bands.

quadLoop.low: The Quad Loop has ~1-2 dB gain over a dipole and better noise rejection. Square or diamond-shaped loop.
quadLoop.medium: Polarization depends on feed point: horizontal when fed on side, vertical when fed at corner. Circumference = 1 wavelength.
quadLoop.high: Mounted high, the Quad is an excellent DX antenna. Less sensitive to environment than a dipole.

quad2el.low: The 2-element Quad has ~6-7 dBi gain - about 1 dB more than a 2-element Yagi with larger area but lighter construction.
quad2el.medium: Quad loops can be built from thin wire (fiberglass spreaders). Lighter than aluminum Yagis with comparable performance.
quad2el.high: Mounted high, the 2-el Quad is a real DX performer. Better signal-to-noise ratio than comparable Yagis.

quad3el.low: 3 elements bring the Quad to ~8-9 dBi. The front-to-back ratio is typically better than a 3-el Yagi.
quad3el.medium: Construction with spreaders makes the 3-el Quad more compact than you'd think. Popular DXpedition antenna.
quad3el.high: Mounted high, the 3-element Quad is a serious DX machine with excellent front-to-back ratio and quiet reception.

sloper.low: The Sloper is a half-wave wire strung at an angle. It radiates toward the slope direction - simple directional antenna with just one mast.
sloper.medium: Upper end should be at a tall mast, lower end near ground. Typical angle: 30-45° to horizontal.
sloper.high: A high Sloper can work surprisingly well for DX in one direction. Multiple Slopers on same mast = switchable directions.

longwire.low: A true long wire is longer than 1 wavelength. This creates multiple radiation lobes - unpredictable but often practical.
longwire.medium: The longer the wire, the lower the main lobe and more side lobes appear. Good ground or counterpoise important.
longwire.high: The long wire was the classic DX antenna of the pioneer era. Now mostly replaced by beams, but still effective when space allows.

cobweb.low: The Cobweb/Spiderweb is a compact multiband antenna. Omnidirectional and lightweight - ideal for restricted rooftops.
cobweb.medium: Works typically on 5 bands (20-10m) with only 3-4m diameter. No rotator needed, but also no gain.
cobweb.high: Mounted high, the Cobweb is a good compromise between size and performance. Not as good as Yagi, but much more inconspicuous.

hexbeam.low: The Hexbeam is a compact directional antenna that works like a 2-element Yagi. Needs less space than classic beams.
hexbeam.medium: Typically 5-band capable with ~4m span. Lighter than a Yagi but similar directivity. Rotator recommended.
hexbeam.high: Mounted high, the Hexbeam is a serious DX contender. About 4-5 dBd gain, good front-to-back ratio.

zs6bkw.low: The ZS6BKW is an optimized G5RV variant with better SWR on multiple bands. 28m dipole with 13.4m ladder line.
zs6bkw.medium: Works well on 40, 20, 17, 12, and 10m. On 80m and 15m with tuner. Less compromise than original G5RV.
zs6bkw.high: Mounted high, the ZS6BKW is a solid multiband DX antenna. Optimized dimensions make it more effective than similar designs.

hb9cv.low: The HB9CV is a compact 2-element directional antenna with phased feed. Designed by Rudolf Baumgartner (HB9CV). Less space than Yagi.
hb9cv.medium: Good front-to-back ratio (~20 dB) with compact design. Boom is shorter than a classic 2-el Yagi.
hb9cv.high: Mounted high, the HB9CV delivers ~5 dBd gain. Especially popular for portable DXpeditions due to small size.

fanDipole.low: The fan dipole consists of multiple dipoles of different lengths at the same feed point. Each band has its 'own' dipole.
fanDipole.medium: Easy to build: Multiple wire pairs spread fan-like. No tuner needed on resonant bands. Watch for element interaction!
fanDipole.high: Mounted high, each dipole element behaves like an individual dipole. Spacing between wires should be 5-10 cm.

spiderbeam.low: The Spiderbeam is a lightweight 5-band beam with tensioned elements. More compact than classic Yagis but similar performance.
spiderbeam.medium: Typical for 20-10m with only 5-6m span. Light enough for portable masts. Rotator recommended for full flexibility.
spiderbeam.high: Mounted high, the Spiderbeam is a serious DX contender. About 5-6 dBd gain on most bands.

moxon.low: The Moxon Rectangle is a compact 2-element antenna with excellent front-to-back ratio. Less boom length than comparable Yagi.
moxon.medium: Especially popular for 6m and 2m due to compact size. About 4-5 dBd gain with 25-30 dB F/B ratio.
moxon.high: Mounted high, ideal for DX in one direction. The bent elements make it mechanically more stable than a Yagi.

logPeriodic.low: The Log-Periodic (LPDA) is a wideband directional antenna. Lower gain than Yagi but works across multiple octaves.
logPeriodic.medium: Ideal when a frequency range needs continuous coverage. No tuner needed, constant impedance across range.
logPeriodic.high: Mounted high, good for monitoring and general operation. Typical 5-7 dBd gain across the entire range.

jPole.low: The J-Pole is an end-fed half-wave vertical for VHF/UHF. No radials needed! Easy to build from copper pipe or twin-lead.
jPole.medium: Omnidirectional with about 2-3 dBd gain. Popular portable antenna for 2m and 70cm. The 'J' part is the matching stub.
jPole.high: Even mounted high, radiation stays low-angle - ideal for range. The Slim-Jim variant is even more compact.

slimJim.low: The Slim Jim is a J-Pole variant made from folded twin-lead. More compact and lighter than the classic J-Pole.
slimJim.medium: ~3-4 dBd gain due to lower radiation angle. Extremely popular as portable or emergency antenna. Rolls up to fit in a pocket.
slimJim.high: Ideal for summits (SOTA) or Field Day. Can be hung from a stick or tree branch. No radials needed.

superJ.low: The Super-J (or Collinear-J) stacks two half-wave elements for ~5-6 dBi gain.
superJ.medium: Basically a 'stacked Slim Jim'. Needs a phasing section between elements. More gain than simple J-Pole.
superJ.high: Excellent portable or permanent antenna when more range than J-Pole is desired. Still no radials needed.

discone.low: The Discone is a wideband vertical antenna. Frequency range typically 1:10 or more. Ideal for scanners and SDR.
discone.medium: Omnidirectional with low-angle radiation. Not optimal on any single band, but unbeatable for wideband reception.
discone.high: Height improves range on all frequencies. Popular choice for amateur + aviation + marine in one antenna.

helix.low: The Helix antenna produces circular polarization - important for satellite work! Multiple turns provide high gain.
helix.medium: Typical for satellite uplinks (e.g., QO-100). 6-12 turns yield 10-15 dBi gain. Axially fed.
helix.high: For satellite work, the helix should point at the satellite. Tracking or fixed orientation for geostationary satellites.

patch.low: The Patch antenna is flat and compact - ideal for microwaves. Can be etched on PCB or built from sheet metal.
patch.medium: Typical 6-8 dBi gain. Multiple patches as array provide higher gain. Popular for 23cm and above.
patch.high: Patch arrays are often used for satellites and EME. The flat form allows discrete installation.

vivaldi.low: The Vivaldi antenna (TSA) is a wideband slot antenna. Exponential slot provides high bandwidth and gain.
vivaldi.medium: Endfire radiation with 8-12 dBi gain. Popular for microwave beacons and EME. Buildable from PCB or sheet metal.
vivaldi.high: Arrays of multiple Vivaldis achieve very high gain. Ideal for microwave DX and EME experiments.

tips.realistic: In practice, ground, buildings, and trees affect the radiation pattern. This display shows typical distortions - your pattern will look different, but the basic characteristics remain.

education.whatIsShortwaveText: Shortwave (SW) are radio waves between 3 and 30 MHz. The special thing: They can be reflected by the ionosphere and 'skip' around the Earth. That's why you can communicate worldwide with little power - without internet or satellites.
education.whatIsIonosphereText: The ionosphere is a layer at 80-400 km altitude where solar radiation 'charges' (ionizes) the air. This charged layer acts like a mirror for shortwave. During the day it's denser (higher frequencies are reflected), at night thinner (lower frequencies pass through).
education.whatIsRadiationPatternText: A radiation pattern shows where your antenna sends its energy. Imagine a lamp: A flashlight radiates focused (like a Yagi), a light bulb in all directions (like a vertical). The diagram shows this 'shape' from above and from the side.
education.whatIsWavelengthText: Wavelength is the length of a radio wave. On 20m it's 20 meters, on 40m it's 40 meters. Important: Antenna height and length are often given in wavelengths. A dipole at '0.5λ height' is 10m high on 20m, but 20m high on 40m!
education.whyAngle: Why does the takeoff angle matter?
education.whyAngleText: The ionosphere reflects shortwave back to Earth. Depending on the angle, the signal lands closer (steep angle) or farther away (low angle). For local contacts you need high-angle radiation, for DX low-angle.
education.whyHeightText: Antenna height (measured in wavelengths) determines the takeoff angle. At λ/4 height, a dipole radiates steeply (NVIS), at λ/2 balanced, at 3/4 λ or more it radiates low (DX).
education.whyGroundText: The ground acts as a reflector. Good ground (moist, salty) reflects better. For vertical antennas, radials create an artificial 'good ground'. Poor ground 'absorbs' energy.
education.whatIsNVISText: NVIS (Near Vertical Incidence Skywave) uses nearly vertical radiation. The signal goes up and comes back down within ~500 km - no skip zone. Perfect for emergency communications and regional nets. Only works on lower bands (160m-40m) with low-mounted antennas.
education.whatIsDXText: DX means 'Distance' - long-distance contacts. The lower the takeoff angle, the farther the signal hops. With multiple reflections (multi-hop), worldwide contacts are possible. You need high-mounted antennas or verticals for this.
education.whatIsSkipZoneText: Ground wave only reaches a few km. The skywave signal lands only beyond a certain distance. In between is the 'skip zone' - no reception possible. High-angle radiation reduces the skip zone.
education.azimuthExplain: The left diagram (azimuth pattern) shows the top view - as if you were looking down at your antenna. The red arrow shows orientation. The blue shape shows in which compass directions the signal is stronger or weaker.
education.elevationExplain: The right diagram (elevation pattern) shows the side view. The horizontal line is the ground. The blue shape shows how steeply the signal goes up. Close to ground = low-angle radiation (good for DX), close to vertical = high-angle radiation (good for NVIS).

tutorial.title: Quick Start Guide
tutorial.welcomeText: This tool helps you understand how your antenna radiates. No formulas, no complex simulations - just visual, intuitive learning.
tutorial.step1Text: Select the antenna type you have or are planning to build. Each type has different characteristics.
tutorial.step2Text: Height is measured in meters AND wavelengths. The same physical height behaves differently on different bands!
tutorial.step3Text: Different bands have different propagation characteristics. Lower bands (160m-40m) work better for NVIS, higher bands (20m-6m) for DX.
tutorial.step4Text: The left diagram shows the top view (where the signal goes horizontally). The right shows the side view (how steep the signal goes up).
tutorial.step5Text: The explanation panel tells you what your setup is best for - NVIS, regional, or DX contacts.
tutorial.step5bText: The specifications show length, gain, and impedance for your antenna. Some antennas (e.g., Inverted-V, Verticals) let you adjust additional parameters like apex angle or radial count.
tutorial.step6Text: Use 'Export' to save diagrams as images. 'Share' creates a link to your current configuration.
tutorial.step7Text: Click 'Compare' to see two antennas side by side. Perfect for evaluating different options.
tutorial.step8Text: The 'Calculator' computes antenna lengths for different frequencies. The 'Map' shows your estimated range on a world map.
tutorial.step9Text: Under 'Solar' you'll find current solar activity data (SFI, K-Index) and band conditions - important for DX!
tutorial.step10Text: Save your favorite configurations as 'Favorites'. Test your antenna knowledge with the 'Quiz'.

solar.sfiExplain: Measures solar activity. Higher = better for higher bands (10m-20m). Below 70 is poor, above 150 is excellent.
solar.kIndexExplain: Geomagnetic activity. Lower is better (0-2 = quiet). Above 5 means likely disturbances and blackouts.
solar.aIndexExplain: 24-hour average of geomagnetic activity. Below 10 is good, above 30 is disturbing.

quiz.title: Quiz - Test Your Knowledge
quiz.question: Question
quiz.good: Very good! You know your stuff.
quiz.q1Question: Which antenna height (in wavelengths) is best for NVIS operation?
quiz.q1Explanation: For NVIS (steep radiation) the dipole should be low - about λ/4. This creates high-angle radiation that bounces back almost vertically from the ionosphere.
quiz.q2Question: What happens to the takeoff angle when you raise your dipole higher?
quiz.q2Explanation: Higher = lower takeoff angle = better DX. The ground acts as a reflector, and the reflection angle changes with height.
quiz.q3Question: Which band is best for DX during low sunspot cycle?
quiz.q3Explanation: 40 meters works well for DX even during low solar activity. 10 and 20 meters need more sunspots.
quiz.q4Opt2: The area between ground wave and first ionospheric hop
quiz.q4Opt3: The null points in the antenna pattern
quiz.q4Explanation: The Skip Zone is where ground wave doesn't reach and skywave hasn't landed yet.
quiz.q5Question: Why does a vertical antenna need good radials?
quiz.q5Opt2: To serve as artificial ground and reduce losses
quiz.q5Explanation: Radials form an artificial conductive ground. Without them, current flows through poor earth.
quiz.q6Question: What is typical for a Yagi antenna?
quiz.q6Explanation: A Yagi focuses the signal in one direction through its directors and reflectors.
quiz.q7Question: Which K-Index is good for DX?
quiz.q7Explanation: Low K values (0-2) mean quiet geomagnetic conditions = stable ionosphere.
quiz.q8Question: What does a high SFI (Solar Flux Index) mean?
quiz.q8Explanation: High SFI (>100) means more solar activity = denser ionosphere = higher MUF.
quiz.q9Question: Which takeoff angle is optimal for DX contacts over 3000 km?
quiz.q9Explanation: Low angles (5-15°) allow long hops via the ionosphere.
quiz.q10Question: What is the advantage of a Magnetic Loop antenna?
quiz.q10Explanation: Magnetic Loops are small (good for limited space) and receive less local noise.

glossary.title: Glossary - Terms Explained Simply
glossary.defShortwave: Radio waves between 3 and 30 MHz (wavelengths 100m to 10m). Can be reflected by the ionosphere to communicate worldwide.
glossary.defWavelength: The length of one complete radio wave. On the 20m band it's 20 meters, on 40m it's 40 meters. Antenna dimensions are often given as fractions of λ.
glossary.defIonosphere: Charged air layer at 80-400 km altitude. Reflects shortwave back to Earth. Denser during day (higher frequencies), thinner at night (lower frequencies work better).
glossary.defPropagation: How radio waves travel from transmitter to receiver. Depends on frequency, time of day, solar activity, and antenna.
glossary.defAzimuth: Shows from above which compass directions the antenna radiates to. Like a floor plan of antenna radiation.
glossary.defElevation: Shows from the side how steeply the antenna radiates upward. Low = DX, steep = NVIS.
glossary.defMainLobe: The direction where the antenna radiates most strongly. Clearly defined on directional antennas.
glossary.defTakeoffAngle: The angle to the horizontal at which most signal is radiated. Low (5-20°) for DX, high (60-90°) for NVIS.
glossary.defNVIS: Near Vertical Incidence Skywave - signal goes nearly straight up and comes back down within ~500 km radius. No skip zone, ideal for regional nets.
glossary.defDX: Distance - long-distance contacts over great distances. The lower the takeoff angle, the farther. With multi-hop, worldwide possible.
glossary.defSkipZone: The area between the end of ground wave and beginning of sky wave where no signal arrives. Size depends on takeoff angle.
glossary.defGroundwave: Signal that travels along the ground. Range only a few km, but always present.
glossary.defSkywave: Signal that goes to the ionosphere and is reflected back. Enables long-distance contacts.
glossary.defGain: How much stronger an antenna radiates in one direction compared to a reference. dBd = vs. dipole, dBi = vs. isotropic. 3 dB more = double power.
glossary.defRadials: Wires at the base of a vertical antenna serving as artificial ground. More radials = better efficiency. 16-32 typical.
glossary.defBalun: BALanced-UNbalanced - converts symmetrical antenna (dipole) to asymmetrical cable (coax). Prevents common-mode currents.
glossary.defSWR: Shows how well the antenna is matched. 1:1 perfect, under 1.5:1 good, over 3:1 bad. High SWR = power is reflected back.
glossary.defFB: For directional antennas: How much stronger the signal goes forward vs. backward. 20 dB F/B means 100x stronger forward.

privacy.title: Privacy Policy
privacy.intro: The protection of your personal data is important to us. This privacy policy informs you about data processing on this website.
privacy.noDataText: This website is a pure client-side tool and does not collect, store, or process any personal data.
privacy.noDataList: No forms, no cookies (except language preference), no tracking, no server-side processing.
privacy.localStorageText: The only stored information is your language preference and whether you've seen the tutorial. This data is saved locally in your browser and not transmitted to servers.
privacy.cloudflareText: This website is served via Cloudflare. Cloudflare may process technically necessary connection data.
